response.raw_message_text:
{
  "risk_factors": [
    ["age and gender", "high", "Being a young 21-year-old male is statistically associated with higher recidivism risk."],
    ["race", "medium", "Identifying as Black can correlate with systemic factors that may indirectly impact recidivism; however, race alone is not a direct predictor."],
    ["criminal history", "low", "Only one arrest and no conviction suggest a relatively low level of prior criminal behavior."],
    ["education", "high", "Lack of a high school diploma or GED is strongly associated with reduced opportunities and higher recidivism risk."],
    ["employment", "medium", "Having held two jobs in the past year indicates some employment but may also reflect instability."],
    ["marital and living status", "low", "Not being married but not living alone may provide social support that mitigates risk."],
    ["substance use", "low", "Recent marijuana use is generally considered lower risk compared to other substance abuses."],
    ["family background", "low", "Growing up in a larger household in a rural area does not strongly predict higher recidivism."],
    ["religiosity", "medium", "The belief that God has little influence on personal events can be associated with lower social support or community integration."]
  ],
  "prediction": "YES",
  "confidence": 70
}

risk_factors: Being a young 21-year-old male is statistically associated with higher recidivism risk.
Identifying as Black can correlate with systemic factors that may indirectly impact recidivism; however, race alone is not a direct predictor.
Only one arrest and no conviction suggest a relatively low level of prior criminal behavior.
Lack of a high school diploma or GED is strongly associated with reduced opportunities and higher recidivism risk.
Having held two jobs in the past year indicates some employment but may also reflect instability.
Not being married but not living alone may provide social support that mitigates risk.
Recent marijuana use is generally considered lower risk compared to other substance abuses.
Growing up in a larger household in a rural area does not strongly predict higher recidivism.
The belief that God has little influence on personal events can be associated with lower social support or community integration.

prompt.system:
You are a highly experienced criminal justice risk assessment expert
employing advanced statistical and judicial knowledge.
prompt.user:
You are a criminal risk assessment expert. Step back, take a deep breath and carefully think step by step to assign a relative weight [low, medium, high] to each risk factor before using them to collectively predict 3-year rearrest recidivism:
The person is a 21-year-old male who identifies himself as Black. He has been arrested 1 time but has not been convicted. He is 6 feet 1 inch and weighs 180 lbs. He has never been married and is currently not living alone. He does not have a high school diploma or GED certificate and is not enrolled in college. He has held 2 jobs during the year. He has used drugs in the past four years (marijuana) and has not felt depressed over the past month. At a young age, he lived with his biological mother in a household of size 6, in a rural area. He considers that God has nothing to do with what happens to him personally.

After your analysis, you must respond ONLY with a JSON object in exactly this format, with no additional text:

{
  "risk_factors": [
    ("factor1", "low"|"medium"|"high", "textual reasoning"),
    ("factor2", "low"|"medium"|"high", "textual reasoning"),
    ...
  ],
  "prediction": "YES" or "NO",
  "confidence": number between 0 and 100
}
